awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Paleoclimatic and Palenvironmental Characterization of Early Pleistocene Sites
awd_abstract_narration:
This research will investigate the impact of climate and environmental change on the migration of early human ancestors out of Africa and their adaptation to novel environments 1.8 million years ago. Previous scholarship on climate-human relationship focused on unique morphological and behavioral adaptations of early humans to hot, arid and open savanna habitats, and causally linked the dispersal of early humans with the development of savanna grasslands in Eurasia. However, evidence for an expansion of a savanna corridor at broad millennial temporal scales and/or at a global continental spatial scale is ambiguous and necessitates consideration that disparate climatic processes operating on narrower temporal scales and local spatial scales may have played a critical role in this cardinal and foundational event. Novel, state-of-the-art, complementary and interdisciplinary methods derived from archaeology and geosciences are well-placed to break new ground by focusing on seasonality and other high-resolution spatial and temporal climatic and environmental patterns as some of the driving forces for dispersal of early Homo. This collaboration of archaeologists, geochemists, paleontologists, and geologists from the United States, Israel, Republic of Georgia, and Australia will explore the unfamiliar pattern of seasonality, climate and environment which early humans faced in the Levant. Knowledge of the type, extent and degree of past biological human adaptation holds promise for illuminating issues on the distributions and capacities of modern humans in varying climatic regimes. The research will provide a platform for fostering professional and public discourse on the interactions throughout time among climate, environment, and human responses, enhancing science education across multiple academic levels, and supporting the recruitment of undergraduate students from underrepresented groups through mentoring aimed to create leaders in scholarship, research and public life. 

The research team will derive new data on the local climate and environment of two archaeological sites in Israel and the Republic of Georgia dating from 2 - 1.2 million years ago, which are the some of the earliest sites of humans out of Africa. Combining new dating methods, archaeological excavations, fossil analyses across the spectra of morphology, histology and chemistry will permit rigorous evaluation of the links between climate, environment and hominin population dynamics. Furthermore, the team will generate new comparative methods for the study of paleoclimatology and paleoecology, which will be used for developing a comprehensive database that will be made publicly available.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Our genus, Homo, evolved in Africa ca. 2.5 million years ago (mya). Around two mya, we find early members of this genus across Eurasia. However, our understanding of the forces that caused this dispersal is unclear. Why was the dispersion in this group of fossil humans and not others? How many dispersals were there? What forces caused these populations to leave, and what forces allowed them to survive in new environments? These are more than theoretical questions. They directly imply how we understand our survival ability in light of the rapidly changing climate. 

It has been proposed that early Homo was strongly adapted to open, arid, and savanna environments. In contrast, others suggested adapting to novel environments allowed early Homo to flourish in Eurasia's temperate climates. We argued that it was more than just the issue of open, hot, and arid vs. wooded, cool, and humid but rather a question of rainfall distribution during the year and the degree of seasonality. Today the Levant has a unimodal rain distribution which falls primarily in the winter. Were there summer rains in the southern Levant that would have facilitated the dispersal of early Homo into Eurasia? Or did they disperse into regions with a similar seasonality pattern?

To start unpacking these questions, we applied several multidisciplinary methods to fossil remains  from the extensive archaeological site of 'Ubeidiya, Israel, dated to 1.6 - 1.2 mya, one of the earliest sites to record evidence of early hominins dispersing from East Africa into Eurasia. 

To look at climate and environmental changes at the site, we analyzed the diet of two common species: deer and vole. We hypothesized that herbivores from open and arid regions would consume tough grasses, resulting in worn teeth. In contrast, herbivores that live in cooler, more humid climates will show less wear. In addition, we looked at chemical signatures locked in the teeth of the same herbivores and freshwater shells. The difference between the chemical composition of the teeth and shell reflects the water temperature and the annual precipitation. 

The novel combination of these results points to a different seasonality pattern and evidence for a more wooded environment with higher mean annual precipitation than today's region. We also noted that our new paleoenvironmental reconstruction of 'Ubeidiya differs from that of another earlier site, Dmanisi from the Republic of Georgia, dated to 1.85 - 1.7 ma. Here there is evidence for a more arid climate and an open habitat. 

How could these different ecological reconstructions be explained?

By analyzing hominin skeletal remains found in 'Ubeidiya, we noted that this population differs from that in Dmanisi. The early hominin present in Dmanisi is small-statured, whereas that in 'Ubeidiya is taller.

We suggest that it is not a one size fits all situation and that the smaller body-sized hominins of Dmanisi were adapted to open habitats. In contrast, the later larger-bodied hominins from 'Ubeidiya were better adapted to closed and more humid environments. Each would have dispersed in a different period, utilizing a different stone tool culture, and thrived in a different ecological setting. 

This research provides novel evidence of early Homo ecology and environments and points to an early origin of the genus Homo's excellent capacity for adaptability to a range of habitats. 

From an ecological and practical perspective, we found that living species also adapt to climate and environmental changes by changing their diet and consuming different food types. In analogy to our current climate crisis, we may be able to expand our repertoire of methodologies to both track and mitigate the local extinction of fauna and habitats. 

Ultimately this study contributes to the ongoing debate in paleoanthropology about the links between climate, environmental change, and hominin population dynamics. Through our academic and public presentations, we have been fostering professional and public discourse on the interactions throughout time among climate, ecology, and human evolution and demonstrate the importance of deepening our understanding of human evolution within the context of past and present environmental change. 

 


Last Modified: 06/21/2023
Modified by: Miriam Belmaker
